question: Question_08_(c)
statement:
A player begins a game of chance by placing a marker in box 2, marked
start. A die is rolled, and the marker is moved one square to the left
if a 1 or 2 is rolled and one square to the right if a 3, 4, 5, or 6 is
rolled. This process continues until the marker lands in square 1, in
which case the player wins the game, or in square 4, in which case the
player loses the game.

\textbf{(c)} Suppose you are told that the eigenvalues of the stochastic
matrix are $\lambda_1 = 1$, $\lambda_2 = 1$,
$\lambda_3 = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}$, $\lambda_4 = -\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}$, and
the corresponding eigenvalues are
$v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$,
$v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$, $v_3$, $v_4$, and
that the eigenvectors form a basis of $\mathbb{R}^4$. Write down a
matrix equation that you would solve in order to find the unique set of
coeï¬cients ${c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4}$ to express the initial state of the
game, $x_0 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$, in terms of
the above basis of eigenvectors. Just write the equation symbolically
using $v_i$, $c_i$, and $x_0$.
sols:
This becomes an $A \vec{x} = \vec{b}$ problem. We want to solve for the
$c_i$, so we start by using the vectors $v_i$ to build A, by writing
$A = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 & v_2 & v_3 & v_4 \end{bmatrix}$, and
$\vec{b} = \vec{x_0}$. So we can write
$\begin{bmatrix} v_1 & v_2 & v_3 & v_4 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ c_3 \\ c_4 \end{bmatrix} = \vec{x_0}$.
Solving this for the $c_i$ would give us the set of coefficients to
express the initial state of the game.
